question.name: 4.3.3 Find integral given areas of regions
question.questiontext:
Regions \(A\) and \(B\) are bounded by the graph of \(f\) and the \(x\)-axis, as shown below.

[[jsxgraph width='250px' height='200px']] JXG.Options.axis.ticks.majorHeight = 10; JXG.Options.axis.ticks.insertTicks = false; JXG.Options.axis.ticks.ticksDistance = 200; JXG.Options.text.fontSize = 16; var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, {boundingbox: {#BB#}, axis: true, showCopyright: false, showNavigation:false}); var f = board.jc.snippet('{#poly#}', true, 'x', true); var ff = board.create('functiongraph', [f,{#ev(a-0.5)#},{#ev(c+0.5)#}],{strokeColor:'#003399',strokeWidth:2}); var i1 = board.create('integral', [{#[a,c]#}, ff], {fillColor:'#003399',fillOpacity:0.15}); i1.curveLeft.setAttribute({visible:false}); /* hide the gliders */ i1.curveRight.setAttribute({visible:false}); i1.label.setAttribute({visible:false}); var ptlabA = board.create('point',{#[a+1,1.2]#}, {name:'A',size:0,fixed:true, label: { offset: [0, 0],anchorX: 'middle', anchorY: 'middle' }}); var ptlabB = board.create('point',{#[c-0.5,1.2]#}, {name:'B',size:0,fixed:true, label: { offset: [0, 0],anchorX: 'middle', anchorY: 'middle' }}); var xaxis = board.create('axis', [[0,0],[1,0]]); board.create('ticks', [xaxis, {#[a,b,c]#}], {strokeColor: '#003399', majorHeight:15, drawLabels: true, label: { offset: [0, -10],anchorX: 'middle', anchorY: 'top' }}); [[/jsxgraph]]

Region \(A\) has area {@A@} and region \(B\) has area {@B@}.

Find the value of \(\displaystyle\int_{@a@}^{@c@}\left(f(x)+{@lin@}\right)\,dx\)

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]
question.generalfeedback:
First, we can break the integral up:

\[\begin{align*} \int_{@a@}^{@c@}\left(f(x)+{@lin@}\right)\,dx &= \int_{@a@}^{@c@}f(x)\,dx+ \int_{@a@}^{@c@}\left({@lin@}\right)\,dx \end{align*}\]

From the facts given in the question, we know \(\displaystyle\int_{@a@}^{@c@}f(x)\,dx={@A@}+{@B@}={@A+B@}\).

Next, we calculate the definite integral:

\[ \begin{align*}\int_{@a@}^{@c@}\left({@lin@}\right)\,dx &= \left[{@integrate(lin,x)@}\right]_{@a@}^{@c@} \\ &= {@linIntegral@} \end{align*}\]

Thus \(\displaystyle\int_{@a@}^{@c@}\left(f(x)+{@lin@}\right)\,dx={@A+B@}+{@linIntegral@}={@ta1@}\).
